content: Head of government of the Crown colony of Singapore from 1955 to 1959 The **chief minister of Singapore** was the [head of government](/wiki/Head_of_government) of the [Colony of Singapore](/wiki/Colony_of_Singapore) until its abolition on 3 June 1959. It was replaced by the office of [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore). The chief minister was appointed by the [governor of Singapore](/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Singapore). The chief minister was the party leader of the majority in the [Legislative Assembly](/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Singapore). ## Background In February 1955, a new constitution, the [Rendel Constitution](/wiki/Rendel_Constitution), was implemented. Singapore would create its first [Legislative Assembly](/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Singapore) with majority of the seats popularly elected, to replace the existing [Legislative Council](/wiki/Legislative_Council_of_Singapore). 25 out of 32 seats would be elected by the general populace, four seats would be allocated to unofficial members appointed by the [governor](/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Singapore), three seats taken by [*ex officio* members](/wiki/Ex_officio_member), respectively the [chief secretary](/wiki/Chief_Secretary,_Singapore), [attorney-general](/wiki/Attorney-General_of_Singapore) and [financial secretary](/wiki/Financial_secretary), while the remaining seat would be for the unofficial speaker of the Assembly nominated by the governor. Moreover, the office of Chief Minister was added, which would be assumed by the leader of the majority party in the Assembly, sharing the responsibility with Chief Secretary, Attorney-General and Financial Secretary. The chief secretary continued to take control over areas such as foreign affairs, defense, administration, internal security, broadcasting and public relations, whereas the power of policy-making for the people's welfare lay in the hands of the chief minister. ## List of chief ministers №NameTerm of officePolitical partyGovernmentElectedTook officeLeft officeGen.1**[David Marshall](/wiki/David_Marshall_(Singaporean_politician))** (1908–1995) Assemblyman for [Cairnhill](/wiki/Cairnhill_Single_Member_Constituency)6 April 19557 June 1956[LF](/wiki/Labour_Front)[Marshall I](/wiki/First_David_Marshall_Cabinet) [LF](/wiki/Labour_Front)–[UMNO](/wiki/Pertubuhan_Kebangsaan_Melayu_Singapura)-[MCA](/wiki/Malaysian_Chinese_Association)(/wiki/1955_Singaporean_general_election)The first Chief Minister of Singapore, he led the [Labour Front](/wiki/Labour_Front) to victory in the [1955 general election](/wiki/1955_Singaporean_general_election). [His chief ministership](/wiki/Chief_ministership_of_David_Marshall) was marked with strikes and riots, a constitutional crisis, and internal issues. He resigned due to the failed [Merdeka](/wiki/Merdeka) mission.2(1)**[Lim Yew Hock](/wiki/Lim_Yew_Hock)** (1914–1984) Assemblyman for [Havelock](/wiki/Havelock_Single_Member_Constituency)8 June 19563 June 1959[LF](/wiki/Labour_Front)[Lim I](/wiki/First_Lim_Yew_Hock_Cabinet) [LF](/wiki/Labour_Front)–[UMNO](/wiki/Pertubuhan_Kebangsaan_Melayu_Singapura)-[MCA](/wiki/Malaysian_Chinese_Association) (1956–1958) [SPA](/wiki/Singapore_People%27s_Alliance)–[UMNO](/wiki/Pertubuhan_Kebangsaan_Melayu_Singapura)-[MCA](/wiki/Malaysian_Chinese_Association) (1958–1959)–[SPA](/wiki/Singapore_People%27s_Alliance)2(2)The second and last Chief Minister of Singapore. He served as Minister of Labour and Welfare in David Marshall's Cabinet and concurrently held this position as Chief Minister.
